User interface (continued)
--------------------------

* Annotation history: A list that displays the history of changes for each label on the document (e.g. who made the change, when the change was made).
* Review tools: Tools that allow Checker users to approve or reject each label, and modify the labels if necessary. Checker users can also add comments for each label.
* Page number and total number of pages: Displays the page number and total number of pages in the document.

User flows
----------

The Annotation screen supports the following user flows:

* Tagger annotation flow:
	1. Tagger selects a classification for the document.
	2. Tagger chooses labels from the relevant list and places them on the document.
	3. Tagger adjusts the position, size, and shape of the labels as needed.
	4. Tagger edits the name and description of the labels as needed.
	5. Tagger changes the color of the labels as needed.
	6. Tagger saves their annotation progress.
* Checker review flow:
	1. Checker reviews the labels that have been placed on the document by Tagger users.
	2. Checker approves or rejects each label.
	3. Checker modifies the labels if necessary.
	4. Checker adds comments for each label.
	5. Checker submits their review.

Use cases
---------

The Annotation screen supports the following use cases:

* Tagger annotation: Tagger users can classify and annotate documents with labels.
* Checker review: Checker users can review and verify the annotations made by taggers.
* Label modification: Tagger and Checker users can edit the name and description of labels, and change their color.
* Label approval/rejection: Checker users can approve or reject labels. Rejected labels are sent back to the Tagger user for modification.
* Commenting: Tagger and Checker users can add comments for each label.
* Navigation: Tagger and Checker users can navigate between pages in the document, and jump to specific pages or headings using the document outline.
* Annotation history: Tagger and Checker users can view the history of changes for each label on the document.

Limitations
-----------

The Annotation screen has the following limitations:

* Only Tagger and Checker users can access the Annotation screen. Other users do not have access to the screen.
* Tagger users can only annotate documents that have been assigned to them. They cannot annotate documents that have not been assigned to them.
* Checker users can only review annotations for tasks that have been assigned to them. They cannot review annotations for tasks that have not been assigned to them.
* The Annotation screen does not support the annotation of documents in formats other than PDF.
* The Annotation screen does not support the annotation of documents with more than 100 pages.
* The Annotation screen does not support the annotation of documents with more than 60 labels per page.

Risk assessment
---------------

The following risks have been identified for the Annotation screen:

* Data loss: There is a risk of data loss if the annotation tool fails to save annotations made by Tagger users.
* Incorrect annotations: There is a risk of incorrect annotations if Tagger users do not follow the correct labeling guidelines.
* Miscommunication: There is a risk of miscommunication if Tagger and Checker users do not use the commenting feature effectively.
* User frustration: There is a risk of user frustration if the Annotation screen has a poorly designed user interface.

Security considerations
-----------------------

The following security considerations have been taken into account for the Annotation screen:

* Access control: Only Tagger and Checker users have access to the Annotation screen. Other users do not have access to the screen.
* Data encryption: All data entered into the Annotation screen, including annotations and comments, is encrypted in transit and at rest.
* Data backup: Regular backups of the annotation data are taken to prevent data loss.

User stories
------------

The following user stories have been identified for the Annotation screen:

**Epic: Annotation**

* As a Tagger user, I want to classify documents so that I can see the relevant labels for the document.
* As a Tagger user, I want to place labels on the document so that I can annotate the document.
* As a Tagger user, I want to adjust the position, size, and shape of the labels so that I can accurately annotate the document.
* As a Tagger user, I want to edit the name and description of the labels so that I can provide accurate information about the annotation.
* As a Tagger user, I want to change the color of the labels so that I can distinguish between different labels.
* As a Tagger user, I want to save my annotation progress so that I can continue annotating at a later time.

**Epic: Review**

* As a Checker user, I want to review the labels that have been placed on the document by Tagger users so that I can verify the accuracy of the annotations.
* As a Checker user, I want to approve or reject each label so that I can indicate my approval or disapproval of the annotation.
* As a Checker user, I want to modify the labels if necessary so that I can correct any errors in the annotations.
* As a Checker user, I want to add comments for each label so that I can provide feedback to the Tagger user.
* As a Checker user, I want to submit my review so that I can complete the review task.

**Epic: Navigation**

* As a Tagger or Checker user, I want to navigate between pages in the document so that I can easily view different parts of the document.
* As a Tagger or Checker user, I want to use the document outline to jump to specific pages or headings so that I can quickly access the information I need.

**Epic: Annotation history**

* As a Tagger or Checker user, I want to view the history of changes for each label on the document so that I can see who made the changes and when they were made.

User interface design
---------------------

The Annotation screen is designed to be user-friendly and efficient for Tagger and Checker users. It has the following features:

* Document preview: A large preview of the document that displays the labels that have been placed on the document.
* Classification dropdown: A dropdown that allows Tagger users to select the classification for the document.
* Labels list: A list of labels that is relevant for the selected classification. Tagger users can select labels from this list and place them on the document.
* Label tools: Tools that allow Tagger users to adjust the position, size, and shape of the labels, and edit the name and description of the labels.
* Color picker: A color picker that allows Tagger users to change the color of the labels.
* Save button: A button that allows Tagger users to save their annotation progress.
* Approve/reject buttons: Buttons that allow Checker users to approve or reject each label.
* Modify button: A button that allows Checker users to edit the labels.
* Comment field: A field that allows Tagger and Checker users to add comments for each label.
* Page number and total number of pages: Displays the page number and total number of pages in the document.
* Page navigation buttons: Buttons that allow Tagger and Checker users to navigate between pages in the document.
* Document outline: A list of headings and pages in the document that allows Tagger and Checker users to quickly jump to specific parts of the document.
* Annotation history: A list that displays the history of changes for each label on the document.

User interface layout
---------------------

The Annotation screen has the following layout:

* The document preview is displayed at the top of the screen, taking up most of the space.
* The classification dropdown and labels list are displayed on the left side of the screen.
* The label tools, color picker, and save button are displayed below the document preview.
* The approve/reject buttons and modify button are displayed below the document preview on the right side of the screen.
* The comment field is displayed below the document preview on the right side of the screen.
* The page number and total number of pages are displayed at the bottom of the screen.
* The page navigation buttons are displayed at the bottom of the screen on the left side.
* The document outline is displayed on the right side of the screen.
* The annotation history is displayed in a popup when the user clicks on a label.

Use cases
---------

The following use cases have been identified for the Annotation screen:

**Use case 1: Annotation**

1. Tagger user logs into the annotation tool.
2. Tagger user selects a task from the list of tasks on the Tasks screen.
3. Tagger user is redirected to the Annotation screen.
4. Tagger user selects the classification for the document from the classification dropdown.
5. Tagger user selects labels from the labels list and places them on the document.
6. Tagger user adjusts the position, size, and shape of the labels as needed.
7. Tagger user edits the name and description of the labels as needed.
8. Tagger user changes the color of the labels as needed.
9. Tagger user clicks the save button to save their annotation progress.
10. Tagger user repeats steps 5-9 until they have finished annotating the document.

**Use case 2: Review**

1. Checker user logs into the annotation tool.
2. Checker user selects a task from the list of tasks on the Tasks screen.
3. Checker user is redirected to the Annotation screen.
4. Checker user reviews the labels that have been placed on the document by the Tagger user.
5. Checker user approves or rejects each label as needed.
6. Checker user modifies the labels as needed.
7. Checker user adds comments for each label as needed.
8. Checker user clicks the submit button to complete the review task.

**Use case 3: Navigation**

1. Tagger or Checker user logs into the annotation tool.
2. Tagger or Checker user selects a task from the list of tasks on the Tasks screen.
3. Tagger or Checker user is redirected to the Annotation screen.
4. Tagger or Checker user uses the page navigation buttons to navigate between pages in the document.
5. Tagger or Checker user uses the document outline to jump to specific pages or headings in the document.

**Use case 4: Annotation history**

1. Tagger or Checker user logs into the annotation tool.
2. Tagger or Checker user selects a task from the list of tasks on the Tasks screen.
3. Tagger or Checker user is redirected to the Annotation screen.
4. Tagger or Checker user clicks on a label on the document.
5. A popup with the annotation history for the label is displayed.
6. Tagger or Checker user reviews the annotation history for the label.
